00007 /*! \mainpage OCTEON PCI driver (OCTEON-PCI-BASE) 
00008 
00009 <b>NOTE:</b> The discussion in these pages pertain to OCTEON PCI base driver
00010              (OCTEON-PCI-BASE) Release 2.2.0. Please refer to the
00011              Release_notes.txt available at OCTEON-SDK/components/driver after
00012              installation of this package for what's new or changed in this
00013              release.
00014 
00015 <br><br>
00016 \section sec0 Introduction
00017 
00018 OCTEON provides the following mechanisms for data transfer across PCI:
00019 
00020 <b>1. Input queues</b> - There are 4 Input queues in CN58xx OCTEON processors
00021     and 32 queues in CN56XX & newer processors to which 32 or 64-byte 
00022     instructions can be written by the PCI host. Based on the information in 
00023     the instructions written by the host, OCTEON can without further assistance
00024     from host read data from host memory and create work queue entries that 
00025     can be scheduled and processed on the OCTEON cores. More details about the 
00026     implementation of Input queues can be found in the OCTEON Hardware manual.
00027 
00028 <b>2. Output queues</b> - There are 4 Output queues in CN58xx OCTEON processors
00029     and 32 queues in CN56XX & newer processors. The queues use 16-byte 
00030     descriptors that  are filled with address of buffers in host 
00031     memory by the PCI host. OCTEON transfers data packets scheduled by the 
00032     OCTEON cores on PCI output ports to these host buffers. More 
00033     details about the implementation of Output queues can be found in the 
00034     OCTEON Hardware manual.
00035 
00036 <b>3. General purpose DMA engines</b> - OCTEON cores can directly transfer data
00037     between host memory and OCTEON L2/DRAM using DMA engines. There are 2 DMA
00038     engines in  CN58xx, 5 in CN56xx and upto 6 in CN63xx & CN68xx, though only 5 are
00039     available for general purpose DMA in CN63xx & CN68xx if the Input/Output queues are
00040     also used. The cores submit PCI DMA instructions to the engines which then
00041     perform the required PCI operations to transfer the data. More details about
00042     the implementation of PCI DMA engines can be found in the OCTEON Hardware
00043     manual.
00044 
00045 
00046 The OCTEON PCI driver for linux (available as a rpm package - OCTEON-PCI-BASE)
00047 provides support for all the three mechanisms described above. The driver has
00048 components that work on the linux host and on the OCTEON cores. 
00049 
00050 <br><br>
00051 OCTEON as a PCI device can function in two modes:
00052 
00053 <b>1. Packet Mode:</b> Packet mode is when the host and OCTEON send packets
00054 across the PCI bus. This mode is most useful when OCTEON is used as a NIC for
00055 carrying network traffic to and from the host.
00056 
00057 <b>2. Coprocessor Mode:</b> Coprocessor mode is when the host sends commands
00058 to OCTEON and waits for a response. This mode is used when OCTEON is performing
00059 offloads for the host system (E.g. IPsec encryption).
00060 
00061 The PCI driver provides support for linux kernel and user-space applications
00062 to communicate with OCTEON in both of these modes. Although the low-level
00063 mechanisms that accomplish this are very similar, the applications are quite
00064 different.
00065 
00066 The following additional packages are provided for OCTEON PCI that use the
00067 features provided by the base PCI driver and deliver added functionality:
00068 
00069 1. OCTEON-PCI-NIC: allows OCTEON to be used a NIC on linux host.
00070 
00071 2. OCTEON-PCI-CNTQ: provides additional software queues that use DMA engines.
00072 
00073 <br>
00074 <br>
00075 <b>NOTE:</b>
00076 
00077 The documentation provided here discuss the features in the base PCI driver
00078 (OCTEON-PCI-BASE) only.
00079 
00080 
00081 <br>
00082 <br>
00083 <br>
00084 \section sec1 PCI Driver Components
00085 
00086 The PCI driver package has two components. The first is a host driver available as
00087 a kernel module that performs the OCTEON device initialization, input and output queue management, interrupt handling and provides interfaces for user and kernel-space applications. In addition to the kernel module, the host components also includes several utilities that can be used to monitor the OCTEON queue statistics and to read/write OCTEON registers and memory. The host component also provides test applications that run in user-space and kernel-space. The test applications require a sample core application that is provided in the package.
00088 
00089 The second is a component which runs on the OCTEON cores. The core component is linked with the core application as a library and provides services to the application via API's. The RPM package also includes sample core applications. They can be found in OCTEON-SDK/applications/pci-core-app when the RPM package is installed. These applications demonstrate request/response (such as when OCTEON runs in co-processor mode), output queue packet transfer and PCI DMA operations and are a good place to start looking at how the API's provided by the core component of the PCI driver can be used in real-life applications.
00090 
00091 
00092 
00093 
00094 Further discussion on the PCI driver is split into the following sections:
00095 
00096 
00097 1.<a HREF=host-main.html > OCTEON Host PCI Driver component</a>
00098 
00099 2.<a HREF=core-main.html > OCTEON Core PCI Driver component</a>
00100 
00101 3.<a HREF=reqresp.html > Request processing using the OCTEON PCI driver</a>
00102 
00103 4.<a HREF=oq-main.html > OCTEON Driver Output Operation </a>
00104 
00105 5.<a HREF=util-main.html > OCTEON PCI Driver - Host Utilities </a>
00106 
00107 6.<a HREF=test-main.html > OCTEON PCI Driver - Test programs </a>
00108 
00109 <br><br>
00110 The directory structure of the sources for PCI driver and associated utilities can be found here:
00111 <a HREF=dir-main.html > OCTEON PCI driver source structure </a>
00112 
00113 Compilation instructions can be found at OCTEON-SDK/components/driver/README.txt
00114 
00115 Select the links provided to the left to refer the source documentation.
00116 
00117 */
00118

00125 /*! \page dir-main OCTEON PCI driver directory structure
00126 
00127 
00128 \verbatim
00129 /usr/local/Cavium_Networks/OCTEON-SDK (default OCTEON OCTEON SDK Location)
00130  | 
00131  |--components
00132     |
00133     |--driver  ($DRIVER_ROOT)
00134         |
00135         |--Makefile (Top-level Makefile to compile the host components)
00136         |
00137         |--README.txt (Compilation instructions)
00138         |
00139         |--core   (Source files for the PCI driver component running on OCTEON cores)
00140         |
00141         |--common (Structures & macros shared by the host and core components)
00142         |
00143         |--bin    (All host executable files and core applications are linked from
00144         |          this directory)
00145         |
00146         |--host
00147             |
00148             |--include  (Header files used by host component files)
00149             |
00150             |--driver
00151             |   |
00152             |   |--linux (Linux specific Host module sources & Makefile)
00153             |   |
00154             |   |--osi   (OS-independent driver implementation)
00155             |
00156             |--api    (User level API for interacting with driver)
00157             |
00158             |--utils  (Source code for user-space utilities )
00159             |
00160             |--test  (Source code for user-space test programs)
00161                |
00162                |--kernel
00163                    |
00164                    |-- req_resp (Linux kernel-space test program to demonstrate
00165                    |             request/response when OCTEON is a co-processor)
00166                    |
00167                    |-- droq_test (Linux kernel-space test program to demonstrate
00168                                   packet transfer on OCTEON output queues)
00169 \endverbatim
00170 
00171 <b>NOTE</b>: The above diagram assumes that the OCTEON-SDK and OCTEON-PCI-BASE packages were installed at their default locations.
00172 
00173 
00174 All host components can be built using the Makefile at $DRIVER_ROOT. The core component is included as a library when compiling the core application. See the README.txt file at $DRIVER_ROOT for more compilation instructions.
00175 
00176 <br>
00177 <br>
00178 <br>
00179 <b>IMPORTANT</b> 
00180 
00181 Only the components of the driver enabled in the Makefile at
00182 OCTEON-SDK/components/driver/host/driver/linux is supported. Other components may be removed in the future and their usability is not guaranteed.
00183 
00184 */

00186 
00187 /*! \page host-main OCTEON Host driver
00188 
00189 <br>
00190  \section hm-sec1 Introduction
00191            The OCTEON host PCI driver allows user-applications to interact
00192  with OCTEON device by providing a means to send requests to the OCTEON input
00193  ports and to forward the responses received from OCTEON. The driver provides
00194  both blocking and non-blocking call support to send requests. It also lets
00195  applications (kernel only) to register callbacks that the driver calls after
00196  request completion. The driver also has a dispatch mechanism by which a kernel
00197  application interested in unsolicited output from OCTEON can register with
00198  the driver to receive those packets.
00199 
00200 <br>
00201  \section hm-sec2  OCTEON Input Queues.
00202           \see request_manager.c  OCTEON_iq.h
00203 
00204           The OCTEON device provides input queues to send data from host to
00205  OCTEON. An application can send requests to the driver using the soft_request
00206  structure. The driver forwards it to OCTEON as an instruction. The driver is
00207  responsible for posting the request, waiting for its response (if expected)
00208  and returning it to the caller, or if the request times-out to notify the
00209  caller about it. A poll thread in the driver keeps track of requests for time-out.
00210 
00211  More detailed discussion on sending requests to OCTEON can be found at <a HREF=reqresp.html > Request processing using the OCTEON PCI driver</a>.
00212 
00213 
00214 <br>
00215  \section hm-sec3  OCTEON Output queues
00216     \see OCTEON_droq.c OCTEON_main.c
00217 
00218           The PCI output queues in OCTEON allow data to be forwarded from OCTEON
00219  to host. Each of these queues is implemented as a descriptor ring in the host
00220  memory with each descriptor pointing to a data buffer and optionally an info
00221  pointer. All data buffers in the descriptor ring are of the same size.
00222  OCTEON can push data into these queues while taking care of splitting the
00223  data and writing it into consecutive buffers. OCTEON can also write a fixed
00224  number of bytes of data along with the length of data to the Info pointer
00225  and write the rest to the data buffer(s). Note that only the info pointer
00226  of the first descriptor carries the additional data for packets that
00227  requires multiple descriptors. OCTEON interrupts the host once a set number
00228  of packets has been sent to the host or a time threshold has been reached. 
00229 
00230 More detailed discussion on receiving data packets from OCTEON can be found at
00231 <a HREF=oq-main.html > OCTEON Driver Output Operation </a>.
00232 
00233 <br> 
00234  \section hm-sec4  Hot Reset
00235   \see OCTEON_device.c
00236 
00237    Hot Reset of a OCTEON target device allows a reset of the OCTEON device
00238    without having to unload the OCTEON device driver. Hot reset can be 
00239    performed even when other modules like the NIC or CNTQ are loaded.
00240    When any such module is loaded, the base driver ensures that these modules
00241    can be put to a quiet state before doing a reset. If not, the reset is
00242    aborted. Before performing a reset, the base driver also waits all pending 
00243    requests to complete and brings the input and output queues to a quiesced
00244    state. Once the reset is done, a new core application can be loaded and the
00245    driver can be used to communicate with OCTEON.
00246 
00247    To perform hot reset, you will need the oct_dbg utility. Compile the sources
00248    in OCTEON-SDK/components/driver/host/utils/oct_dbg.c. Select option 't' to
00249    initiate a Hot Reset. Check the system log messages to see if the reset 
00250    completed successfully. 
00251 
00252 
00253 
00254 <br>
00255  \section hm-sec5  OCTEON DMA Engines 
00256 
00257 OCTEON provides general purpose DMA engines which can be used by core software
00258 to DMA data from or to the host. These engines are used by the core driver to
00259 copy the response for instructions directly into host memory.
00260 
00261 The API's for sending responses and for PCI DMA read/write operations are
00262 discussed in more detail at <a HREF=core-main.html > OCTEON Core PCI Driver component</a>.
00263 
00264 
00265 
00266 
00267 <br><br>
00268   \section hm-sec7 OCTEON device identifier
00269 
00270   The driver can support multiple OCTEON devices in a single instance. The
00271   maximum OCTEON devices supported is determined by the MAX_OCTEON_DEVICES
00272   setting in components/driver/host/include/OCTEON_config.h.
00273 
00274   Each OCTEON device in the system is assigned an id starting with 0 for the
00275   first OCTEON device. The driver configures devices in the order it is
00276   passed to it by the PCI subsystem in the linux kernel. Usually, this matches
00277   the order of devices in the PCI bus scan.
00278 
00279 
00280 <br><br>
00281 
00282   \anchor Octdevconf
00283   \section hm-sec8 OCTEON device configuration
00284 
00285 
00286   The OCTEON device configuration is maintained by the driver in
00287   oct_config_data.h. This header file includes a default configuration for every
00288   OCTEON processor family. The configuration data is maintained in
00289   statically initialized data structures using the data types defined
00290   in OCTEON_config.h. 
00291 
00292 
00293   If you want to change the default configuration, you can modify the values in
00294   these configuration data structures. This will affect all OCTEON devices of
00295   the same type (for e.g. if you modify the CN56XX configuration, all CN56XX
00296   devices in the system will have the same new configuration).
00297 
00298   If you wish to use a custom configuration for a particular OCTEON device,
00299   follow the procedure outlined below:
00300   - Create a copy of the default configuration data corresponding to the OCTEON
00301     processor family of interest.
00302      Lets call this new configuration as custom_conf.
00303   - Open components/driver/host/driver/osi/OCTEON_device.c and modify the
00304      oct_conf_info structure.
00305      - Change the conf_type field for the OCTEON that you wish to customize
00306         from OCTEON_CONFIG_TYPE_DEFAULT to OCTEON_CONFIG_TYPE_CN3XXX_CUSTOM
00307         for a CN38XX/CN58XX device, OCTEON_CONFIG_TYPE_CN56XX_CUSTOM for a
00308         CN56XX device or OCTEON_CONFIG_TYPE_CN63XX_CUSTOM for a CN63XX device.
00309      - Change the custom field to the address of the custom_conf structure.
00310 
00311 <br>
00312 
00313 
00314 
00315 <br><br>
00316   \section hm-sec9  The /proc entries
00317 
00318   The driver creates entries in the /proc filesystem for each OCTEON device
00319   in the system. The /proc entries identifies each OCTEON device by its id.
00320   For e.g., entries for the first OCTEON (with device id 0), will be under
00321   /proc/OCTEON0.
00322 
00323   The following files can be found for each OCTEON device:
00324   - <b>/proc/OCTEONX/configreg (ReadOnly)</b>
00325      dumps the config space registers for the device.
00326   - <b>/proc/OCTEONX/csrreg (ReadOnly)</b>
00327      dumps the BAR0 CSR registers for the device.
00328   - <b>/proc/OCTEONX/status (ReadOnly)</b>
00329      dumps the status of each Input and Output Queue including the current 
00330      position of indexes and the register values associated with each queue.
00331   - <b>/proc/OCTEONX/stats (ReadOnly)</b>
00332      dumps the statistics for each Input and Output Queue, including the
00333      number of packets, total bytes and bytes since the last time this field
00334      was read.
00335   - <b>/proc/OCTEONX/npireg (ReadOnly; exists for CN38XX/58XX devices only)</b>
00336      dumps the BAR0 PCI Windowed registers for the device.
00337 
00338 
00339 
00340 
00341 <br><br>
00342   \section hm-secc Compiling the Host driver
00343 
00344     Steps to compile the host driver can be found at OCTEON-SDK/components/driver/README.txt. 
00345     
00346 
00347   \section hm-deprec  Deprecation Notice
00348 
00349     The following items have been deprecated/changed from the driver sources
00350     in the 1.0.0 release.
00351 
00352     - OCTEON_soft_request_t : The changes are described in
00353      \ref octsoftreqformat "Soft request structure changes"
00354 
00355     - CN56XX_WORKAROUND : This flag was used to enable support for CN56XX Pass1
00356     and is now deprecated.
00357 
00358 
00359 
00360 */
